prs.truncated_body:
**Description**

This PR introduces a new `MaxTxGasLimit` feature that allows node operators (particularly the sequencer on single-sequencer rollups) to configure a maximum gas limit for individual transactions in the transaction pool. When configured via the `--txpool.maxtxgas` flag, any transaction exceeding this limit will be rejected by the transaction pool with an `ErrTxGasLimitExceeded` er

prs.title: op-acceptance-tests: interop: loadtest: unify stopping conditions
prs.truncated_body:
Previously, the Burst and Steady schedules had different stopping conditions: budget depletion and timeout, respectively.

This was undesirable for two reasons:

1. It was challenging to tune the timeout and budget to ensure Steady tests succeeded.
2. Burst tests ignored `NAT_STEADY_TIMEOUT` but succeeded on go test timeout expiration.

Making both schedulers report success on budget deplet

commits.message:
op-acceptance-tests: interop: loadtest: unify stopping conditions

Previously, the Burst and Steady schedules had different stopping conditions:
budget depletion and timeout, respectively.

This was undesirable for two reasons:

1. It was challenging to tune the timeout and budget to ensure Steady
   tests succeeded.
2. Burst tests ignored NAT_STEADY_TIMEOUT but succeeded on go test
   timeout expiration.

Making both schedulers report success on budget depletion and timeouts significantly
reduces the cognitive overhead when running load tests.

prs.title: sha256: replace assembly core with intrinsics
prs.truncated_body: Our implementation of the sha256 core using SHA-NI instructions seems to have pre-dated the intrinsics based on Kevin's comments. It contained seemingly random `nop`s, which also suggests the scheduling was highly tuned for some specific CPU.  Using intrinsics gives the compiler more freedom for instruction scheduling and register allocation.  In practice, the performance seems extremely similar.

prs.title: docs/rofl: Update ROFL diagram
prs.truncated_body:
Based on the recent feedback from the hackathon and our partners the ROFL diagram needs to be updated to reflect new features:

- TEE was replaced with "ROFL App in TEE" and ROFL App was replaced with "Containers"; we needed to put the docker/podman into bigger context.
- removed "Other Chains"; some of the hackathoners wanted to use ROFL signed transactions to communicate with non-Oasis chains

commits.message:
docs/rofl: Update ROFL diagram

Based on the recent feedback from the hackathon and our partners the
ROFL diagram needs to be updated to reflect new features:

- TEE was replaced with "ROFL App in TEE" and ROFL App was replaced with
  "Containers"; we needed to put the docker/podman into bigger context.
- removed "Other Chains"; some of the hackathoners wanted to use ROFL
  signed transactions to communicate with non-Oasis chains
- Sapphire -> Sapphire Confidential EVM Chain; because some users went
  on ROFL docs directly without knowing what Sapphire is
- added new Sapphire->ROFL "Secrets" connection to reflect a new feature
- added "Encrypted Storage" to reflect a new feature
- added "appd REST" to reflect the feature with connection to Sapphire
  for signing smart contract transactions
- "Outer World" -> "Web 2 Services"; this terminology is more common in
  the crypto community

prs.title: feat(s2) v2
prs.truncated_body:
## Description

Implements v2 of the Secret Service:

- fully idempotent API (major rework of the musig2 API)
- `OneOf` errors over the wire https://github.com/komora-io/terrors/pull/20
- massive code size decrease in the S2 crates (more logic shifted to the caller)

Enables full restartability and multi-machine redundancy of S2 servers. 

### Tasks

- [x] `Archive`, `Serialize` and `D
